title-group.article-title: Passive control of n-dimensional chaotic complex nonlinear systems

abstract.p: In this paper we investigate the control of n-dimensional chaotic complex nonlinear systems by using passive control theory. These complex systems have been introduced and studied recently in our investigations. Based on the property of the passive system, an approach is stated to design the passive controller and realize the control of these systems. As an example, we apply this approach to convert the chaotic attractors of the complex Lü system into the trivial, nontrivial equilibrium points, periodic (limit cycle) and quasi-periodic solutions. This example appears in several fields of physics and engineering, e.g. nonlinear electronic circuits and communications. A block diagram of this example using Matlab/Simulink is constructed. The analytical results of the controllers which have been calculated by using this approach are tested numerically and good agreement is obtained.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In the literature, since the chaos control problem was considered by Ott et al. (1990), many valuable control methods have been developed to control chaotic systems, such as impulsive control (Chen et al. 2004), adaptive control (Efimov 2006), sliding mode control (Chiang et al. 2007), fuzzy control (Yau and Shieh 2007), optimal control (Tian and Yu 2000), digital redesign control (Guo et al. 2000), backstepping control (Zhang et al. 2004), and many others. The concept of passivity of nonlinear systems has aroused new interest in the nonlinear control field (Willems 1972; Vidyasagar 1979; Byrnes et al. 1991; Calcev 1998; Pogromsky 1998; Xie et al. 1998; Chua 1999; Wen 1999; Lou and Cui 2007; Wang and Liu 2007a,b; Wei and Luo 2008; Xiang-Jun et al. 2008; Budiyono et al. 2009; Kemih 2009; Chen and Liu 2010; Sangpet and Kuntanapreeda 2010a,b; Wei et al. 2010).

The concept of passivity plays an important role in systems, signal and control theory. It arises naturally in many areas of science and engineering (Budiyono et al. 2009). In 1972, passivity was studied for nonlinear systems (Willems 1972; Vidyasagar 1979). The passivity theory is considered as an alternative tool for analyzing the stability of nonlinear systems. Later, the passivity theory has been found to be a nice tool in several areas such as stability (Lou and Cui 2007), complexity (Chua 1999), signal processing (Xie et al. 1998), synchronization (Pogromsky 1998; Wang and Liu 2007b), fuzzy control (Calcev 1998) and chaos control (Wen 1999).

The main idea of passivity theory is that the passive properties of system can keep the system internally stable. So, to make the system stable, one can design a controller which renders the closed-loop system passive using passivity theory (Wei et al. 2010). Passivity is part of the general theory of dissipativity (Willems 1972; Byrnes et al. 1991). The passive control has many advantages, e.g. clear physical interpretation, less control effort or ease in implementation (Wei et al. 2010). Passive systems, such as linear circuits containing only positive resistors, are stable.

During the last decade the passivity theory has played an important role in designing an asymptotically stabilizing controller for chaotic nonlinear systems with real variables (Wen 1999; Wang and Liu 2007a,b; Wei and Luo 2008; Xiang-Jun et al. 2008; Kemih 2009; Chen and Liu 2010; Wei et al. 2010). There also exist, however, interesting cases of nonlinear systems, where the main variables participating in the dynamics are complex (Gibbon and McGuinnes 1982; Fowler et al. 1983; Mahmoud et al. 2007a,b,c, 2008a,b, 2009; Mahmoud and Mahmoud 2010a,b; Liu and Liu 2011; Mahmoud and Ahmed 2011; Mahmoud and Mahmoud 2011) Therefore, it is important to investigate the control of n-dimensional chaotic nonlinear systems with complex variables via passive control theory, which we hope to achieve in this paper.

The organization of this paper is as follows. Section 2 presents the description of n-dimensional chaotic complex nonlinear systems. An approach is stated based on the property of the passive system to realize the control of these systems. Section 3 illustrates the validity of this approach by converting, for example, the chaotic attractors of the complex Lü system (Mahmoud et al. 2007c; Mahmoud and Mahmoud 2010a) to the trivial, nontrivial equilibrium points, periodic (limit cycle) and quasi-periodic solutions. The analytical forms of the controllers of this example are derived. In Section 4, the numerical results are illustrated to emphasize the validity of the theoretical investigations. The simulation of the chaotic complex Lü after control are designed by using Matlab-Simulink in Section 5. There is a good agreement between numerical and simulation results. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section 6.

sec.title: 2. Chaotic complex nonlinear systems
sec.p: Consider the n-dimensional chaotic complex nonlinear system as follows: (1)z·=f(z,z¯), where the state complex vector z = (z1, z2, … , zn)T ∈ Cn, zl = ulr + juli (l = 1, 2, … , n), j=-1, f = (f1, f2, … , fn)T is a smooth vector field, superscript T denotes transpose, subscripts r and i stand for the real and imaginary parts of the state complex vector, respectively, dots represent derivatives with respect to time and an overbar denotes complex conjugate variables.
In this paper we study the phenomenon of the control of chaotic complex nonlinear systems of the form (1) via passive control theory.

statement.title: Remark 1.
statement.p: The n-dimensional chaotic complex nonlinear system (1) can be rewritten in the real form as (2)u·=F(ulr,uli), where u = (u1r, u1i, u2r, u2i, … , unr, uni)T ∈ ℝ2n is a state real vector (l = 1, 2, … , n), ulr, uli are real functions and F is a smooth nonlinear vector field.

statement.title: Remark 2.
statement.p: Most of chaotic complex systems can be described by (1), such as complex Lorenz, Chen and Lü systems (Fowler et al. 1983; Ning and Haken 1990; Mahmoud et al. 2007a,c; Mahmoud and Mahmoud 2010a; Mahmoud and Ahmed 2011). For example, the chaotic complex Lü system (Mahmoud et al. 2007c; Mahmoud and Mahmoud 2010a) is (3)z·1=α(z2-z1),z·2=βz2-z1z3,z·3=1/2(z¯1z2+z¯2z1)-γz3, where z = (z1, z2, z3)T, f = (f1, f2, f3)T = (α(z2 − z1), βz2 − z1z3, 1/2(z¯1z2+z¯2z1)-γz3)T, α, β and γ are positive parameters, z1 = u1r + ju1i, z2 = u2r + ju2i are complex functions and ulk (l = 1, 2, k = r, i), z3 = u3r are real functions. System (3) exhibits chaotic behavior when α = 40, β = 22 and γ = 5 (Mahmoud et al. 2007c; Mahmoud and Mahmoud 2010a). The chaotic complex Lü system is a five-dimensional continuous real autonomous system. It is interesting to note that the (positive) Lyapunov exponent of complex Lü system is λ1 = 3.03 (Mahmoud et al. 2007c; Mahmoud and Mahmoud 2010a). This system has a trivial equilibrium point (0, 0, 0, 0, 0), as well as a whole circle of nontrivial equilibrium points given by the expression: (γβcosϑ, γβsinϑ, γβcosϑ, γβsinϑ, β), for ϑ∈0,2π]. If we choose ϑ=π/2 and using the values of the above parameters, system (3) has the nontrivial equilibrium point (0, 10.4881, 0, 10.4881, 22). For more dynamical properties about this system, see Mahmoud et al. (2007c) and Mahmoud and Mahmoud (2010a).

sec.title: 2.1. An approach of passive control for chaotic complex nonlinear systems (1)
sec.p: We consider the chaotic complex nonlinear systems with the controller in the general form as follows: (4){z·=f(z,z¯)+g(z,z¯)Θ,y=h(z,z¯), where Θ = (θ1, θ2, … , θm)T is the input (or ‘controller’), θs = θsr + jθsi (s = 1, 2, … , m), n > m, y = (η1, η2, … , ηm)T is the output, ηs = ηsr + jηsi, f and the m columns of g are smooth vector fields and h is a smooth mapping.

The real form of system (4) can be written as (5){u·=F(ulr,uli)+G(ulr,uli)θ,η=H(ulr,uli), where θ = (θ1r, θ1i, θ2r, θ2i, … , θmr, θmi)T and η = (η1r, η1i, η2r, η2i, … , ηmr, ηmi)T. For every initial condition u(0) and every input θ(·), there is a maximally defined solution u(·) of the system (5), and corresponding output η(·) (Liberzon et al. 1992). We suppose that the vector field F has at least one equilibrium point.

statement.title: Definition 1
statement.p: (Wang and Liu 2007a,b). The system (5) is a minimum phase system if LGH(0)=∂/H∂uG(ulr,uli) (the directional derivative of H in the direction of G)is nonsingular and u = 0 is one of asymptotically stabilized equilibrium points of F(ulr, uli).

statement.title: Definition 2
statement.p: (Byrnes et al. 1991; Chen and Liu 2010). The system of the form (5) is said to have relative degree [1, 1, … , 1] at u = 0 if the matrix LGH(0) is nonsingular.

statement.title: Definition 3.
Definition 4
statement.p: (Kemih 2009; Chen and Liu 2010). The system (5) is said to be passive if there is a nonnegative function V : U → ℝ, called the storage function, which satisfies V(0) = 0, such that (8)V(u)-V(u(0))≤∫0tηT(τ)θ(τ)dτ. The physical meaning of passive system is that the energy of the nonlinear system can be increased only through the supply from an external source. In other words, a passive system cannot store more energy than that supplied externally.

statement.title: Remark 3.
statement.p: When we let ζ = Ω(u), system (5) will be changed into the following generalized form: (9){ζ·=ϕ0(ζ)+ψ(ζ,η)η,η·=ρ(ζ,η)+σ(ζ,η)θ, where a new coordinate of the system (5) is (ζ, η), locally defined in the neighborhood of the origin, ζ ∈ ℝ2n−2m and σ(ζ, η) is nonsingular for all (ζ, η) in the neighborhood of the origin. By designing a suitable controller θ, the system (9) may be passive by using a state feedback in the form: (10)θ=ς(ulr,uli)+κ(ulr,uli)ξ, where ς(ulr, uli), κ(ulr, uli) are smooth functions, κ(ulr, uli) is invertible for all u and ξ is an external signal vector (Byrnes et al. 1991; Wei and Luo 2008). Thus, the equilibrium point of the system (9) can be asymptotically stabilized by applying the nonlinear controller θ (Xiang-Jun et al. 2008).

statement.title: Remark 4.
statement.p: Setting η = 0 in system (9), yields the zero dynamic system: (11)ζ·=ϕ0(ζ). The system (9) is called minimum phase, if its zero dynamics is asymptotically stable.

sec.p: Theorem 1 of Wang and Liu (2007a,b) can be extended to system (5) for 2m controllers as follows.

statement.title: Theorem 1.
statement.p: If the system (5) has a relative degree [1, 1, … , 1] at u = 0 and system (5) is a minimum phase system, the system (9) will be equivalent to a passive system and asymptotically stabilized at an equilibrium point if we let the local feedback control as follows: (12)θ=σ-1(ζ,η)[-ρ(ζ,η)-(∂/W(ζ)∂ζψ(ζ,η))T-ɛη+ξ], where the Lyapunov function of ϕ0(ζ) is W(ζ), ɛ is a positive real value and ξ is an external signal vector that is connected with the reference input.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Suppose that the storage function takes the form: (13)V(ζ,η)=W(ζ)+1/2ηTη, where V(ζ, η) is the Lyapunov function. Differentiating V with respect to t, then we have (14)d/dtV(ζ,η)=∂/W(ζ)∂ζζ·+η·Tη,=∂/W(ζ)∂ζϕ0(ζ)+∂/W(ζ)∂ζψ(ζ,η)η+η·Tη,=∂/W(ζ)∂ζϕ0(ζ)+∂/W(ζ)∂ζψ(ζ,η)η+(ρ(ζ,η) +σ(ζ,η)θ)Tη. Because system (5) is a minimum phase system, the inequality can be obtained as (15)∂/W(ζ)∂ζϕ0(ζ)≤0, where W(ζ) is the Lyapunov function of ϕ0(ζ) (zero dynamics). So, (14) can be written as (16)d/dtV(ζ,η)≤∂/W(ζ)∂ζψ(ζ,η)η+(ρ(ζ,η)+σ(ζ,η)θ)Tη. Substituting from Equation (12) into the inequality (16), we get (17)d/dtV(ζ,η)≤ξTη-ɛηTη. By integrating both sides of inequality (17), we have (18)V(ζ,η)-V(ζ(0),η(0))≤∫0tξT(τ)η(τ)dτ-ɛ∫0tηT(τ)η(τ)dτ. Setting a = V(ζ(0), η(0)) and according to the definition of V(ζ, η), it is obvious that V(ζ, η) ≥ 0. So the inequality (18) becomes (19)∫0tξT(τ)η(τ)dτ+a≥ɛ∫0tηT(τ)η(τ)dτ+V(ζ,η),≥ɛ∫0tηT(τ)η(τ)dτ. According to Definition 3, the system (9) is a passive system.

Because W(ζ) is radially unbounded, it follows from Equation (13) that V(ζ, η) is also radially unbounded, so that the closed-loop system is bounded state stable at [ζT, ηT]T. This means that we can use the local feedback control described in the form (12) to regulate the system (9) to an equilibrium point, and Theorem 1 is proved.

sec.p: For illustration in Section 3, this approach is applied to control attractors of the chaotic complex Lü system (3) as an example of n-dimensional chaotic complex nonlinear systems.

sec.title: 3. An example
sec.p: Let us now study the passive control of the chaotic complex Lü system (3) as an example of chaotic complex nonlinear systems (1) using the approach of Section 2.

The chaotic complex Lü system with control function can be written in the form: (20)z·1=α(z2-z1),z·2=βz2-z1z3+θ1,z·3=1/2(z¯1z2+z¯2z1)-γz3, where θ1 = θ1r + jθ1i is the control function. Separating the real and imaginary parts, we obtain the real version of system (20) as (21)u·1r=α(u2r-u1r),u·1i=α(u2i-u1i),u·2r=-u1ru3r+βu2r+θ1r,u·2i=-u1iu3r+βu2i+θ1i,u·3r=u1ru2r+u1iu2i-γu3r. Let ζ= [ζ1, ζ2, ζ3]T = [u1r, u1i, u3r]T, η=[η1r, η1i]T = [u2r, u2i]T, thus, system (21) has the form (22)ζ·1=α(η1r-ζ1),ζ·2=α(η1i-ζ2),ζ·3=ζ1η1r+ζ2η1i-γζ3,η·1r=-ζ1ζ3+βη1r+θ1r,η·1i=-ζ2ζ3+βη1i+θ1i. System (22) can be characterized as (23){ζ·=ϕ0(ζ)+ψ(ζ,η)η,η·=ρ(ζ,η)+σ(ζ,η)θ, where (24)ϕ0(ζ)=[-αζ1-αζ2-γζ3], ψ(ζ,η)=[α00αζ1ζ2],ρ(ζ,η)=[-ζ1ζ3+βη1r-ζ2ζ3+βη1i], σ(ζ,η)=[1001].

statement.title: Theorem 2.
statement.p: The chaotic system (21) is a minimum phase system.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Choose a storage function as (25)V(ζ,η)=W(ζ)+1/2ηTη,=W(ζ)+1/2(η1r2+η1i2), where W(ζ)=1/2(ζ12+ζ22+ζ32), W(0) = 0.

The zero dynamics of the system (23) describes the internal dynamics and occur when η = 0, i.e. (26)ζ·=ϕ0(ζ). Differentiating W(ζ) with respect to t, we obtain (27)W·(ζ)=∂/W(ζ)∂ζζ·=∂/W(ζ)∂ζϕ0(ζ),=[ζ1ζ2ζ3][-αζ1-αζ2-γζ3]T,=-(αζ12+αζ22+γζ32)≤0. Since W(ζ) > 0 and W·(ζ)<0, it can be concluded that W(ζ) is the Lyapunov function of ϕ0(ζ) and ϕ0(ζ) is globally asymptotically stable which means that the controlled system (23) is a minimum phase system.

At the same time, we can compute the matrix LGH(0) as (Byrnes and Isidori 1988; Liberzon et al. 1992) (28)LGH(0)=[1001], where H=[u2ru2i] and G=[0010000010]T is computed by comparing (21) with (5). Since the matrix LGH(0) is nonsingular and according to Definition 1 we ensure that system (21) is a minimum phase system. On the other hand, the system (21) has vector relative degree [1, … , 1] according to Definition 2. So system (21) can be equivalent to a passive system, and Theorem 2 is proved.

Because our system (21) is minimum phase system and has vector relative degree [1, … , 1]. So system (21) is appropriate to apply Theorem 1, and we can derive the controllers as (29)θ1r=-αζ1-(β+ɛ)η1r+ξ1,θ1i=-αζ2-(β+ɛ)η1i+ξ2, since ζ = [ζ1, ζ2, ζ3]T = [u1r, u1i, u3r]T, η = [η1r, η1i]T = [u2r, u2i]T, so (29) can be written as (30)θ1r=-αu1r-(β+ɛ)u2r+ξ1,θ1i=-αu1i-(β+ɛ)u2i+ξ2. Therefore, the complex Lü system (21) after control becomes (31)u·1r=α(u2r-u1r),u·1i=α(u2i-u1i),u·2r=-u1ru3r-αu1r-ɛu2r+ξ1,u·2i=-u1iu3r-αu1i-ɛu2i+ξ2,u·3r=u1ru2r+u1iu2i-γu3r.
The analytical results of the controllers (30) will be tested numerically in Sections 4 and 5.

statement.title: Remark 5.
statement.p: When we let ɛ > 0 and ξ1 = ξ2 = 0, the chaotic attractors of complex Lü system will be controlled to be stable at the trivial equilibrium point.

statement.title: Remark 6.
statement.p: The attractors of the chaotic complex Lü system after control are converted to nontrivial equilibrium points if ɛ > 0 and ξ1=u1r*u3r*+αu1r*+ɛu2r*,ξ2u1i*u3r*+αu1i*+ɛu2i*, where (u1r*,u1i*,u2r*,u2i*,u3r*) is the nontrivial equilibrium point for system (21).

statement.title: Remark 7.
statement.p: The solutions of (31) may be converted to periodic (limit cycle) or quasi-periodic solutions if ɛ > 0 and ξ1 = A1 cos ω1t, ξ2 = A2 sin ω2t where A1, A2 are the amplitudes and ω1, ω2 are the frequencies of ξ1, ξ2 respectively.

sec.title: 4. Numerical results
sec.p:
In this section, we solve system (3) numerically (using e.g. Mathematica 7 software). We choose α = 40, β = 22, γ = 5 for which a chaotic attractor exists (Mahmoud et al. 2007c) and with initial conditions t0 = 0, u1r(0) = 1, u1i(0) = 2, u2r(0) = 3, u2i(0) = 4, u3r(0) = 5. In Figure 1(a), we plot the state variable u2i versus t of system (3) (before control), and other state variables can be similarly plotted. The chaotic attractors of (3) are plotted in Figure 1(b) and (c) in (u1r, u3r) and (u1i, u2i) planes, respectively. Figure 2 shows the solution of the chaotic complex Lü system (31) after control with the same choice of the parameters and initial conditions of Figure 1 and according to Remark 5 we choose ɛ = 10, ξ1 = ξ2 = 0. From Figure 2 the chaotic attractors of Figure 1 are controlled to trivial equilibrium point. According to Remark 6 we select ɛ = 10, ξ1 = 0, ξ2 = 755.142, and these attractors of Figure 1 approach to nontrivial equilibrium point as shown in Figure 3. On the other hand, these chaotic attractors convert to periodic attractors when we choose (according to Remark 7) ɛ = 10, ξ1 = 100 cos t, ξ2 = 200 sin 2t, as demonstrated in Figure 4. However, if we choose ξ1 = 150 cos 17t, ξ2 = 140 sin 9t, they are converted into quasi-periodic solutions (see Figure 5). Figures 2, 3, 4 and 5 show the controllers θ1r and θ1i are valid to control the chaotic attractors of our example, while, Figures 2(a), 3(a) and 4(a) clarify that the control is achieved after small values of the time t. sec.title: 5. Simulation of system (31)
sec.p:
In this section, the simulation of system (31) is designed by using Matlab-Simulink 7.4 to confirm the validity of the approach of Section 2. Simulink allows us to build quickly block diagram models of dynamic systems. Simulink is widely used in control theory to simulate systems after control (Beucher and Weeks 2006). The simulation of the chaotic complex Lü system after control is illustrated in Figure 6. The block diagram model of system (31) (Figure 6) contains five channels which realize the state variables u1r, u1i, u2r, u2i, u3r, respectively. The block diagram model of system (31) is running with the same choice of the parameters and initial conditions of Figures 2, 3, 4 and 5. The simulation observations of the chaotic complex Lü system after control are displayed in Figures 7, 8, 9 and 10 which agree with the numerical results of Figures 2, 3, 4 and 5, respectively. So, there is a good agreement between numerical results and simulation results. Therefore, the theoretical proposed controllers (30) are valid to control the chaotic attractors of our example. Figure 8.
Simulation observations of system (31) when ɛ = 10, ξ1 = 35, ξ2 = 20 (nontrivial equilibrium point): (a) (t, u2i) plane; (b) (u1r, u3r) plane; (c) (u1i, u2i) plane.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper the passive control method is applied to achieve control of chaotic complex nonlinear systems which have been introduced recently in the literature. This paper studies chaos control of n-dimensional chaotic complex nonlinear systems using the passive control method. An approach is proposed based on the definitions of passive control theory to achieve chaos control of these systems. For example, this approach is applied to the chaotic complex Lü system. The analytical forms of the controllers (30) are verified by numerical and simulation results. The block diagram model (simulation) of system (31) is designed by using Matlab-Simulink in Figure 6. An excellent agreement is found between numerical calculations in Figures 2, 3, 4 and 5 and simulation observations in Figures 7, 8, 9 and 10, respectively. It is clear from these Figures that the chaotic attractors of the complex Lü system are converted into the trivial, nontrivial equilibrium points, periodic (limit cycle) and quasi-periodic solutions.

The proposed control approach is easy to realize and can be applied to several other chaotic complex nonlinear systems. This approach may be extended to realize the synchronization of chaotic and hyperchaotic complex nonlinear systems and results are expected to appear in a future publication (Mahmoud et al. 2012).

Finally, it is hoped that the results that are reported and illustrated in this paper increase our knowledge of the chaos control of complex dynamical systems, which is still far from what has been achieved to date for dynamical systems with real variables.
